explanation:
The report is not correct. MISRA Rule 2.2 targets executed operations whose removal would not change program behaviour. In this source the OS_DEBUG macro is defined as empty (#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__)). After preprocessing the invocation OS_DEBUG("recvfrom: %s\n", strerror(errno)); leaves no logging call and the argument expressions are not evaluated; only the trailing semicolon becomes an empty (null) statement. No runtime operation (no call to strerror, no logging) is executed here, so there is no executed operation that could be removed to change behaviour. Therefore this source line, as given with OS_DEBUG defined empty, does not constitute the kind of "dead code" banned by Rule 2.2.

Note: if the debug macro were defined so that arguments were evaluated or if it expanded to a runtime no-op that is executed, then a static analysis could validly consider that a dead operation. Also take care not to pass expressions with required side-effects into logging macros that may be disabled via an empty definition.
